awd_titl_txt: A Pioneering Test of Stellar Population Complexity Outside the Milky Way
awd_abstract_narration:
The investigator will test the uniqueness of the Milky Way Galaxy's chemical composition.  Their goal is understanding how other galaxies change with time, based on observations of stars in the Milky Way (MW). Observations of individual stars in the MW show that the chemistry and the motions of stars are related. These relationships have guided our understanding of how other galaxies change over time and chemically enrich the Universe. Studying the changes in other galaxies over time is extremely difficult. The project team will pioneer new techniques for testing if these patterns occur in the Andromeda Galaxy, the nearest galaxy that is similar to the MW. These measurements will provide insight into that galaxy's history, the uniqueness of the MW, and the usefulness of these systems for tracing how galaxies have grown since the Big Bang.  

To analyze existing high-resolution, near-infrared (NIR) spectra spanning a large fraction of Andromeda's bulge and disk, the project team will first construct a library of Simple Stellar Population (SSP) models based on theoretical isochrones and nearly 400,000 stellar spectra observations. The public release of this NIR library will fill a gap in the suite of SSP libraries available to the community.

The project team will apply this library in two approaches to modeling the Andromeda integrated spectra, one using multi-component spectral fitting and one using machine learning with the SSP models as a training set. The comparison of the two approaches will be used to evaluate the consistency and robustness of the results in different parts of the galaxy. This program will constrain the presence of overlapping stellar populations in the inner regions of Andromeda with distinct dynamical and chemical properties that reflect their diverse histories, information that previously has been measured only in the MW. By revealing how similar Andromeda is to the MW in this important regard, this project will clarify to what extent our high-resolution picture of the MW can be applied to interpreting the unresolved starlight in other galaxies. More generally, these results will test theories of bulge and inner disk evolution and how that evolution is reflected in the constituent stellar populations.

This program also supports efforts to promote scientific literacy to two important groups local to the project team: Utah's refugee community and visitors to Utah's national parks. The team will develop astronomy-themed workshops as part of an after-school program that helps middle- and high-school students from refugee families integrate into American classrooms and find social support. These workshops will promote positive perceptions of science and teach critical thinking, communication, and computational skills to students who face unique challenges to their education because of their family histories. The project also includes an extension of a high-impact outreach internship program to bring astronomy education to about 18,000 visitors at Bryce Canyon National Park. These two efforts will be linked by a visit of students from the refugee community to Bryce Canyon for an immersive outdoor experience under some of the US's darkest skies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project's scientific goal was to assess the uniqueness of the Milky Way Galaxy and explore how to use the Milky Way in measuring galaxy evolution elsewhere in the Universe. Data of individual stars in the Milky Way show that the chemistry and the motions of stars are related. These relationships have guided humanity's understanding of how galaxies evolve and chemically enrich the Universe. However, measurements of these relationships in other galaxies are extremely difficult to make. The project team pioneered new techniques to test if these patterns also occur in the Andromeda Galaxy, the nearest galaxy that is similar to the Milky Way.

Two valuable products resulting from the analysis were 1) a new library of high-resolution, infrared simple stellar population spectral templates, and 2) a software package to fit multiple spectral templates to data with complex informative priors. The template library is publicly available, and the software package will be soon.

Excitingly, the team did detect the presence of kinematically and chemically distinct stellar populations in the inner regions of Andromeda, for the first time in the light from old stars. And the details are intriguingly complex. In the center of the galaxy, they found two populations whose properties align closely with those of the "bar" and "bulge" in the Milky Way, albeit with a slightly different spatial distribution. On one side of the Andromeda Galaxy's disk, there clearly appears to be two co-spatial populations, with kinematics and chemistry correlated as in the Milky Way (our so-called "thick" and "thin" disks). However, on the other side of the galaxy, the data are consistent with a single population, or two populations whose kinematics have been blurred together such that they are indistinguishable. This asymmetry may offer insight into the relatively recent merger/interaction history of Andromeda, given the proximity of some companion galaxies to that side of the disk.

These measurements will provide insight into that galaxy's history, the uniqueness of the Milky Way, and the usefulness of these systems for tracing how galaxies have grown since the Big Bang.  

This project supported the research training of two graduate students, both of whom were thus able to develop computational and model-fitting expertise and other professional skills, including networking, proposal writing, and presenting scientific results. An undergraduate student, mentored by one of the graduate students, also carried out research on this project as part of an NSF REU program.

Finally, this project also supported astronomy outreach interns, who introduced people to the wonders of the night sky using the incredible dark skies at Bryce Canyon National Park. The interns organized telescope viewing programs, led full moon hikes, and gave constellation tours from the canyon rim. All together, they guided roughly 5000 visitors to a better understanding of what is visible from Earth, how astronomers learn about deep-space objects, and the importance of preserving dark-sky environments for future generations.
